subject: Re: [junit] question about Assert.assertEquals
msgSnippet: ... The false-if-null thing I did not know, although it makes perfect sense now that I think of it. ... I read your conclusion to be that it is therefore all
messageBody:
>So said Kevin Klinemeier on 2003-05-06 --------------------
>
>--- "J. B. Rainsberger" <jbrains@...> wrote:
>> Some people will suggest using an instanceof check in your equals
>> method. This fails if you subclass Point.
>
>Eh? instanceof returns true if the left-hand side argument is a
>subclass as well. It also returns false if its null, which makes it
>particularly handy for objects.

The false-if-null thing I did not know, although it makes perfect sense now that I think of it.

>If you mean that it ends up breaking symmetry if subclassed, I'll
>agree. However, as Joshua Bloch pointed out (to me at least) in
>Effective Java, "There isn't any way to extend an instantiable object
>and add an aspect while preserving the Equals contract". You're either
>going to break symmetry or transitivity no matter how you do it.

I read your conclusion to be that it is therefore all right to code equals() in such a way as to report falsely that two objects are equal, because there's no way to make a superclass and subclass follow the equals() contract. Is that what you are saying? If it is, then I think it's all the more important to implement equals() in a failsafe way, since Bloch claims (and I don't doubt him, but I would need to think about it) that a subclass with more attributes than its superclass cannot be equal to it.

Assuming that I did a reasonable job of expressing that, what do you say?
